channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Majority of Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Dismantle Police Department
item.description: Some cities are starting to to heed calls to “defund the police,” as lawmakers push proposals for greater police accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington, D.C.
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Powderhorn Park in Minneapolis on Sunday called for the defunding of the city’s Police Department.

item.title: George Floyd Protests Add New Front Line for Coronavirus Doctors
item.description: Many physicians wish to show solidarity at the demonstrations, but some fear a second wave of infection will follow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Yuki Iwamura/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mount Sinai nurses and doctors cheered on protesters at Union Square in Manhattan on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Jumps the Border, Overwhelming Hospitals in California
item.description: Hospitals are airlifting patients to facilities hundreds of miles away to handle an influx of Americans and U.S. green card holders sickened in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler/Reuters
item.media:description: A health care worker in protective gear treated a patient with the coronavirus at the El Centro Regional Medical Center in El Centro, Calif., last month.

item.title: ‘Because of Sex …’
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally for transgender people in Brooklyn on Sunday.

item.title: Stock Markets Jump Globally After Wall Street’s Rally: Live Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sentiment in financial markets has been unsteady in recent days as traders on Wall Street have confronted new worries about the pandemic.

item.title: Jericho Brown, Carmen Maria Machado and Thomas Page McBee on What Pride Means Now
item.description: Fifty years after the first Pride March, the authors Jericho Brown, Carmen Maria Machado and Thomas Page McBee reflect on a complicated moment for the L.G.B.T.Q. community.
item.dc:creator: Jericho Brown, Carmen Maria Machado and Thomas Page McBee
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Audra Melton; Yael Malka for The New York Times; Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

item.title: Why Protest Movements Are ‘Civil’ Only in Retrospect
item.description: Once history has endorsed a social movement, people tend to simplify it and downplay the opposition it faced. But while movements are happening, historians say, they are always messy.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Alex Brandon/Associated Press
item.media:description: Demonstrators protesting George Floyd’s death this month stood in front of the Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial in Washington. During his lifetime, Dr. King was highly unpopular.

item.title: Why Andrea Jenkins Is Somber, but Optimistic
item.description: The Minneapolis councilwoman, the first black, openly transgender woman to be elected to public office in the U.S., talks about racial equity, how poetry informs her work and where we go from here.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Massara
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrea Jenkins has been on the Minneapolis City Council since 2018. “The problems that led to George Floyd being murdered have been present in Minneapolis, in Minnesota, in the United States of America, for a very, very long time,” she said. “Since the beginning of this country.”

item.title: More Than 2,000 Black People Were Killed by White Mobs During Reconstruction, New Study Shows
item.description: The Equal Justice Initiative has documented a rate of killing in the period following the Civil War that was far higher than the decades that followed.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Mickey Welsh/Montgomery Advertiser, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Bryan Stevenson, the founder of the Equal Justice Initiative, speaks at the E.J.I. Legacy Pavilion in Montgomery, Ala., in January.

item.title: How the Pride March Made History
item.description: Fifty years after the first march, prominent organizers and activists tell its story and talk about how it spread across the globe.
item.dc:creator: David Kaufman
item.media:credit: Michael Evans/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Christopher Street Liberation Day March in New York City in 1970.

item.title: As Travel Starts Back Up, Wineries and Other Food-and-Drink Enclaves Get Creative
item.description: Distilleries, cooking schools, wineries and food halls from California to South Minneapolis are adjusting to social distancing and hygiene in a new era of travel.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Sloss

item.title: Who’s a Bot? Who’s Not?
item.description: It sometimes seems that automated bots are taking over social media and driving human discourse. But some (real) researchers aren’t so sure.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts
item.media:credit: Chris Gash

item.title: Man Expected to Plead Guilty in Golden State Killer Case and Avoid Death Penalty
item.description: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr. is expected to accept a life sentence without the possibility of parole for a series of murders and rapes in the 1970s and ’80s as part of a plea agreement, one victim and close relatives of two other victims said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Heather Murphy
item.media:credit: Daniel Kim/The Sacramento Bee, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr., suspected of being the man known as the Golden State Killer, surrounded by lawyers as he appeared in Sacramento Superior Court last year.

item.title: Cup Foods, a Minneapolis Corner Store Forever Tied to the Death of George Floyd
item.description: The corner market, the site of demonstrations and memorials, reopened on Monday. It has been a fixture in the neighborhood for more than three decades.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cup Foods reopened its doors on Monday, three weeks after George Floyd was killed by the police outside the Minneapolis store.

item.title: Pride Goeth, or Is It Gone?
item.description: As many Americans lose faith in the future, fewer say they’re very proud to be Americans at all.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: To Gain Public’s Trust, Should Members of Congress Stop Trading Stock?
item.description: Federal investigations and public outcry over senators’ stock trades amid the coronavirus crisis have renewed interest in limiting what lawmakers can do with their savings.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kelly Loeffler of Georgia, left, spent months fighting accusations that she traded on insider information that helped avert thousands of dollars in losses to her portfolio.

item.title: Conservative Christians See ‘Seismic Implications’ in Supreme Court Ruling
item.description: A ruling that protects the rights of gay and transgender workers could impact how conservative groups operate their own institutions.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: “I find this to be a very sad day,” Franklin Graham, an evangelical leader, said after a Supreme Court ruling on Monday protected gay and transgender workers. “I don’t know how this is going to protect us.”

item.title: Mayor Bottoms Tightens Rules on Atlanta Police's Use of Force
item.description: Mayor Keisha Lance Bottoms issued a series of executive orders after the shooting of Rayshard Brooks, which has stirred protests and pushed the city into a broader reckoning over policing.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Dustin Chambers/Getty Images
item.media:description: Protesters on Monday took part in the March on Georgia, which was organized by the N.A.A.C.P., in downtown Atlanta.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: A troubling pattern emerges in parts of the U.S. that began lifting restrictions earlier than others.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Supreme Court LGBTQ Ruling Pushes Workplace Dynamic Already in Motion
item.description: The Supreme Court decision gives plaintiffs leverage, but companies large and small are still expected to face legal cases over their policies.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: 777 Portraits Myrtle Beach, SC
item.media:description: Jacqueline Cote, right, reached a settlement with Walmart in 2016 over the denial of health benefits for her spouse, Diana Smithson, left. After a Supreme Court decision on Monday, a lawyer said, “employees shouldn’t even have to bring a lawsuit” in such cases.

item.title: Alan Hurwitz, Teacher Who Turned to Bank Heists, Dies at 79
item.description: Once a respected educator in Detroit, he developed a crack addiction and robbed 18 banks in three months, earning the name the “Zombie Bandit.” He died of Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Paul Novak
item.media:description: Alan Hurwitz had a career in education before, in his 50s, he turned to bank robbery.

item.title: Man Is Shot at Protest Over Statue of New Mexico’s Conquistador
item.description: Two statues of Juan de Oñate are being removed after long-simmering tension between Native Americans and Hispanics over Spain’s conquest of New Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.category: Albuquerque Museum of Art and History
item.media:credit: Adria Malcolm for The New York Times
item.media:description: The statue called “La Jornada” features Juan de Oñate (center) on the property of the Albuquerque Museum. The statue was vandalized after a petition for its removal began circulating.

item.title: Coronavirus Study: 1 in 5 People Worldwide at Risk
item.description: Roughly 1.7 billion people have at least one of the underlying health conditions that can worsen cases of the coronavirus, a new analysis shows.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: China Daily/Reuters
item.media:description: Medical workers tended to a coronavirus patient in Wuhan, China, in February. A study found that about 4 percent of the world’s population would require hospitalization if infected.

item.title: ‘Say Thank You Say I’m Sorry’
item.description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning poet Jericho Brown writes for the Book Review about life during the pandemic.

item.title: ‘Weather’
item.description: The poet Claudia Rankine writes for the Book Review about the climate in America at this moment.
item.media:credit: Ike Edeani for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re out / to repair the future.” The poet Claudia Rankine.

item.title: NOAA Chief Violated Ethics Code in Furor Over Trump Tweet, Agency Says
item.description: Neil Jacobs violated the agency’s scientific integrity policy with a statement last year backing the president’s inaccurate claim that a hurricane was headed for Alabama, a panel found.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Evan Vucci/Associated Press
item.media:description: Neil Jacobs, NOAA’s acting administrator, during a hurricane-season briefing with President Trump in the White House last month.

item.title: Oluwatoyin Salau, Missing Black Lives Matter Activist, Is Found Dead
item.description: Ms. Salau, 19, was found dead along with a 75-year-old woman in Tallahassee, Fla., the police said. Their deaths are being investigated as homicides.
item.dc:creator: Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:credit: Hali Tauxe/Democrat - USA TODAY Network
item.media:description: Oluwatoyin Salau, 19, speaking in front of the Tallahassee Police Department during a protest last month.

item.title: Hillary Clinton Backs Eliot Engel, in Her First House Primary Endorsement of 2020
item.description: Mr. Engel, a longtime New York representative, is trying to fend off a serious challenge from his left by Jamaal Bowman, who has been endorsed by Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Erin Scott/Reuters
item.media:description: Representative Eliot Engel of New York, the chairman of the powerful House Foreign Affairs Committee, faced criticism this spring for his absence from his district during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: BIPOC: What Does It Mean?
item.description: The acronym, which stands for black, Indigenous and people of color, is suddenly everywhere. Is it doing its job?
item.dc:creator: Sandra E. Garcia
item.media:credit: Brandon Bell/Getty Images
item.media:description: A BIPOC Mothers March walk from the Third Police Precinct Station to a memorial site for George Floyd in Minneapolis, Minn. on June 14, 2020.

item.title: A Half-Century On, an Unexpected Milestone for L.G.B.T.Q. Rights
item.description: The Supreme Court’s surprising 6-to-3 ruling in favor of gay and transgender rights was perhaps the strongest evidence yet of how fundamentally and unpredictably American views have changed.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Jeremy W. Peters
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court ruled Monday that the 1964 Civil Rights Act protects gay and transgender workers from workplace discrimination.

item.title: Kansas City Police Investigate Vandalism of Memorial to Lynching Victim
item.description: The memorial to Levi Harrington, a black man killed in Kansas City, Mo., in the 1880s, had been vandalized before.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: The African American Heritage Trail of Kansas City, Mo.
item.media:description: The Levi Harrington memorial in Kansas City, Mo. It was installed in 2018 as part of a project by a nonprofit legal advocacy group, the Equal Justice Initiative.

item.title: V.O.A. Directors Resign After Bannon Ally Takes Charge of U.S. Media Agency
item.description: Amanda Bennett and Sandra Sugawara told Voice of America employees that they had offered their resignations to Michael Pack, a conservative activist pushed by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Agency for Global Media
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amanda Bennett, the director of Voice of America, resigned on Monday.

item.title: Gorsuch Leads Way on Landmark L.G.B.T. Rights Decision
item.description: One conservative group said the justice’s opinion in the L.G.B.T. rights case had betrayed the legacy of Justice Antonin Scalia, whose seat on the court he has held since 2017.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justice Neil M. Gorsuch led a 6-to-3 majority in declaring that gay and transgender workers are protected by the Civil Rights Act.

item.title: Biden and D.N.C. Raised Nearly $81 Million in May, a New High
item.description: The former vice president had struggled with fund-raising throughout much of the primary campaign, but the pace of giving has sharply increased.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s fund-raising haul in May was more than 30 percent higher than what he and the Democrats raised in April.

item.title: FDA Revokes Emergency Coronavirus Use of Malaria Drugs
item.description: The agency said that a review of some studies showed that the drugs’ potential benefits in treating Covid-19 did not outweigh the risks.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.category: Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:credit: George Frey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Food and Drug Administration said that hydroxychloroquine was “unlikely to be effective” in treating the coronavirus.

item.title: Museums Embrace Art Therapy Techniques for Unsettled Times
item.description: Several institutions are preparing to reopen with an awareness of a new mission as people struggle with loss and unrest.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: Portraits of Families in Protest
item.description: Parents actively show their children how to speak out and take a stand against inequality.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron and Cheriss May

item.title: Civil Rights Law Protects L.G.B.T. Workers, Supreme Court Rules
item.description: The court said the language of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits sex discrimination, applies to discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: RG & GR Harris Funeral Homes Inc
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tiffany Munroe on Sunday in Brooklyn during a rally to call attention to violence against transgender people of color.

item.title: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Case on California Sanctuary Law
item.description: The case concerned a state law that limits cooperation with agents seeking to detain immigrants released from state custody.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court gave no reasons why it declined to hear the case, as is its custom.

item.title: 25 Million Applications: The Scramble for N.Y.C. Affordable Housing
item.description: Entrants to the city’s housing lottery have waited years, through a tiresome and complex process. Now the system is getting an overhaul.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Haag
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: With New Policies, Cities Seek a ‘Seismic Shift’ in Policing
item.description: The district attorney for Atlanta has said he will decide by midweek on whether to file criminal charges in the fatal police shooting of Rayshard Brooks.
item.media:credit: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times

item.title: How to Donate Blood
item.description: What you need to know about donating in a time of crisis.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Wartik
item.media:credit: Jon Nazca/Reuters

item.title: How One California High School Celebrated Graduation During a Pandemic
item.description: The students and parents pushed and prodded over 10 weeks for an exception to Gov. Gavin Newsom’s shelter-in-place order.
item.dc:creator: Anne Daugherty
item.media:credit: Anne Daugherty
item.media:description: After arriving on Paradise High School’s Om Wraith field for the school’s first ever drive-in graduation ceremony, Brian Enright, a senior, takes in the scene.

item.title: Trump’s Niece, Mary Trump, to Publish Book With ‘Harrowing’ Revelations
item.description: Mary Trump will say that she was a source of The New York Times’s coverage of the president’s tax returns. The Times declined to comment on the claim.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Alexandra Alter
item.category: Too Much And Never Enough: How My Family Created the World's Most Dangerous Man (Book)
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump walking off Air Force One at Joint Base Andrews, Md., on Sunday.
